numbered_ace_sentences: 1. Some elite colleges give an advantage to legacy applicants.
2. A legacy applicant is an applicant whose parent attended the college.
3. Non-legacy applicants do not have legacy status.
4. Students whose parents are in the top 5% of the income rank have a much higher chance of admission.
5. There is a dip for non-legacy applicants between 75% and 90%.
6. I wonder why there is a dip for non-legacy applicants between 75% and 90%.
7. I ask whether it is legal that a college admits an applicant based on financial status.
8. I ask whether it is legal that a college admits an applicant based on legacy status.
9. I ask whether this is true for non-elite colleges.
10. I think that this situation is not fair.
11. First-generation students are students whose parents did not attend college.
12. First-generation students would be at a significant disadvantage in this situation.
13. Ideally, educational opportunity should not be based on factors that a student cannot control.
14. My parents did not go to elite colleges.
15. This situation makes me less confident about applying to an elite college.
16. The headline is: Who is applying: you or your parents?
